attribs.name: proficiencies
attribs.current:
Armor: Light Armor, Medium Armor, All Armor, Shields
Weapons: Battleaxe, Handaxe, Throwing Hammer, Warhammer, Simple Weapons, Martial Weapons
Tools: Brewer's Supplies, Dragon Chess, Vehicles (Land)

attribs.name: repeating_classfeature_-KpCu2NHUmeZm3dWYTXi_content
attribs.current:
You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

Defense
While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

attribs.name: repeating_classfeature_-KpCu2PlomGKkBT8XS8n_content
attribs.current: On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points.

attribs.name: classfeatures_chat_var
attribs.current: {{Class Features=[Fighting Style (Fighter)](~repeating_classfeature_-kpcu2nhumezm3dwytxi_action), [Second Wind (1/1, Short or Long Rest)](~repeating_classfeature_-kpcu2plomgkkbt8xs8n_action)}}

attribs.name: repeating_trait_-KpD04YBZDnGKctdUsst_content
attribs.current: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

attribs.name: repeating_trait_-KpD0w3newgYPc-nTLCp_content
attribs.current: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

attribs.name: repeating_trait_-KpD1DJbUN3chS8yzl4c_content
attribs.current: You have proficiency with the Battleaxe, Handaxe, Throwing Hammer, and Warhammer.

attribs.name: repeating_trait_-KpD1a8pn9uIFcVIspzM_content
attribs.current: You gain proficiency with the artisan’s tools of your choice: Smith’s Tools, Brewer’s Supplies, or Mason’s Tools.

attribs.name: repeating_trait_-KpD33edtq1H6kNSSFU0_content
attribs.current: Whenever you make an Intelligence (History) check related to the origin of stonework, you are considered proficient in the History skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

attribs.name: repeating_offense_-KpDCvHgbc8SxFIC-mZn_content
attribs.current: Made of interlocking metal rings, chain mail includes a layer of quilted fabric worn underneath the mail to prevent chafing and to cushion the impact of blows. The suit includes gauntlets.

attribs.current: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.

attribs.name: repeating_offense_-KpDD6H-Zp8N5EnZUbaW_attack_string
attribs.current: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.

attribs.name: personality_traits
attribs.current: I face problems head-on. A simple, direct solution is the best path to success.

attribs.name: backstory
attribs.current:
Let's start at the beginning.

I was born to clan Shotstagger. The great city of Sigil was my home. So let's stop there and look at the Shotstagger history a bit. Then you'll understand a little more about how I got here. Not that I know entirely where 'here' is.

The Shotstaggers were a proud people. In generations past, our forefathers brought renown to our name. With that renown they laid a claim in Sigil under the watchful eye of the lady protector. Or, as she prefers to be called, the Lady of Pain. Now this lady, she is an all powerful deity within the city, and yet she refuses to allow anyone to worship her.

Go figure.

In any case, being the proud, hardheaded peoples my ancestors were, they threw down and tossed gold at her feet. Apparently, Moradin wasn't good enough for them. The bastards. So the great and merciful Lady of Pain does what she does best. She started sending them to her endless mazes. Only Moradin had other ideas. See, we didn't just betray the creator, we turned our backs on him. Well he got the last laugh.

The Lady of Pain thinks she sends us to her mazes to die. But no. Moradin makes sure we live. He pulls us from her grasp and tosses us out into the planes like rag dolls. He cares not where we land, only that we do. This way we suffer. Every moment we live is a moment we suffer the pain of betrayal. We live knowing we have no honor. It is worse than death.

So now that you know why we get thrown around, let's talk about where I was tossed.

I was one of the lucky ones. I had heard of others who were thrown into realms of fire, or even nothingness, only to, what I can assume, was die horribly. I was thrown to the material plane of existence. Right back where I should be. I took solace in that. I thought that maybe that meant it was over.

Boy was I ever wrong.

So let's fast forward a few years. I fell in with a military company for some local militia group. Nothing fancy. But, it seems I had what it took. A green horn if I was ever anything. I worked hard and rose the few ranks. Again, I would like to point out that this militia was barely that in name. But the grog was sweet and the recognition wasn't bad.

So here we are, our first big 'real' mission. We get to clean out some infested mausoleum. Awesome. Rats, maybe a skeleton or two? Whatever it was, we were ready, prepared, and all that good shit.

Pffft, Yeah right ...

We get inside and right off the bat I know something is a little queer. But,, our first mission. So I pushed forward. There were a few rats. Even one skeleton. Easy enough. What we didn't expect was the Vampire. Needless to say, the small company was wiped clean in a matter of seconds. Except for me.

Yup. I was the one left alive to deliver a message. See? There it is. Moradin making sure to snuff what little honor I may have gained in one fell swoop. Now, not only was I to live knowing that I was a betrayer, but I also get to live knowing I was a coward. And I say coward, because it's true. I could have fought back. I could have tried my hand at the Vampire, but I didn't. I trembled in fear and nodded my head. Then, later that evening, I went back to the village and told everyone that the Mausoleum was now home to a Vampire and that she had killed everyone except me.

Right then, moving on. Nothing really matters anyway.

So a few years later I run into this Halfling. Nice enough fellow. He makes me forget that I'm a piece of shit. It's refreshing.

But again, I've jumped ahead. Let me tell you how we met.

It wasn't long after my encounter with the Vampire. My life was now a simple path between cities doing odd jobs here and there for what little coin I could muster. Some times it was as simple as moving things from point A to point B. Sometimes it required a little more finesse. Once or twice I was even asked to take care of bigger 'pests'. But no matter where my days led me, the nights were always the same. Whatever local tavern I could find and whatever swill I could buy on my days earnings. The idea was to drown myself in ale until I passed out. Where I woke up the next morning was where I began my next day.

This went on for a long while. Until one night. I was doing the usual routine when this Halfling comes up to me. Mind you, no one has said two words to me in damn near a year, so when he greets me and tells me of how brave my clan is, I simply take another swig of my cheap ale.

I wish I could say that I wish he had just stopped there and moved on, but the truth is far darker than that. However, it certainly has a bright light at the end of the tunnel.

So this Halfling, he was a bugger of a fellow. Kept insisting that the Shotstagger name was something to be proud of. Finally I gave in and spoke back. "Bug off, half pint. Ye got the wrong Dwarf." But like I said, he was a pestering little shite. He went on and on about how only a Shotstagger could help him find his family. Just buggering and talking nonstop. And, just when I was about to break his little neck because I'd had enough, he said something that stopped me in my tracks.

"Listen. I don't know you, I don't know your past, but I know a person's past cannot define them. Regardless of how hard, or bad it was, you have to understand that the past is not the future. You've built a stage and at this point you decide if you're going to read the script that you think is already written, or if you're going to ad-lib something new. Something that is better than what you think is supposed to be there. So I'll leave you alone. But even if I don't know you, I want you to know that I believe you're better than this."

I don't know if it was the ale, or if what he said really made sense to me, but the next thing I knew I was stumbling to my feet and chasing after the little bastard. When I finally caught up to him I said two words to him. "I'm in."

The next few weeks we were running the countryside looking for clues to his family ordeal. Along the way we would stop to help those in need. Real hero kinda stuff. For the first time since I was cast out of Sigil, I felt alive. Truly alive. All because this little pecker-head believed in me when I didn't even believe in myself.

Anyway, along one of these trips we came across a village who asked us to look for some fruit. Whatever. We agreed that a little down time would be nice and finding fruit seemed easy enough. We asked a few questions, gathered what information we could, and headed out. Turns out that this place is called The Sunless Citadel. Not a bad name. I kinda dig it.

Dig it? See what I did there? (Because it was all underground.)

So we didn't even get to this Sunless Citadel. In fact, when we got within looking distance, the first thing we saw was a small Kobold crawling out of a huge chasm. It looked beaten and bloodied, scared shitless, running for it's life. I honestly didn't know what to think. And then the Dragon came out after the Kobold.

Well, now that things were in a little more perspective, I did what any good Dwarf would do when faced with a Dragon. I pulled my axe and charged. Seems Kade, the Halfling, had the same idea. Fore he followed suit. Soon enough we had the great white beast bested. In a flurry it flew off in fear of our combined might! A spectacular display of greatness.

However, the Kobold was still running. This puzzled me. Why would the little guy run when the danger was no longer present. The answer was simple. You see, as I turned back to the chasm, I saw a horde of kobolds screaming and yapping as they were clawing their way out of the ravine. As soon as they were topside they started for us. Now I'm good in a scrap. I can take my fair share and dish out four times as much, but even I know when I'm outnumbered. So I started running.

The mob was after them. Flight or die was the name of this game. Now, as a Dwarf, I am no speed demon. I could keep pace with the other two as they moved ahead. For the most part. But we were still losing ground. Or rather, I was. It all ended well enough. Kade, and his tricks, manged to hide us from the viscous mob as they ran by. Something to do with shadows and such. I cared not. I was simply glad to be alive.

When the dust had settled, there was the matter of the lone Kobold. A queer bit, he was. Shaken to wits end. Kade and I managed to calm him a bit. If only for a bit. He was one hell of a skittish little thing. Every odd sound would him a twitch.

For the longest while he trusted no one. Not even us. However, we did manage to pull him around. He was never the courageous one. In fact, all he wanted to do was please Kade and I. Truth be told, I was just glad the little bugger hadn't tried to eat my face off. Not that Kobolds eat faces or anything. It was only a rumor I heard. Once.

Let me tell you about my favorite hunt. I call it a hunt because that's exactly what it was. We come to this village, It's always a village, and they tell us of this dragon who's demanding sacrifices and blah blah blah. You know the story. 

We get to tracking this dragon and all that good BS. This hunt is beautiful form the beginning. Everything is lining up, I couldn't have planned it better if I tried. We get this thing trapped in a cave. Meepo, believe it or not the short guy was pretty handy with a spell. Kade was awesome as well. And then it happened.

As I stood over the body of the now dead green dragon, I looked over to my comrades. My friends. I would never tell them, I am too Dwarf for that. But I liked these guys. I really did. I felt, well, right being with them. I haven't felt this way in a long time. I belonged.

Life was good. From that point forward I knew I was in good hands. Even if Meepo was jumpy, he was a good friend to have around. Kade could really get out of a situation when it was needed. Together, there wasn't anything we couldn't accomplish.

One day, while hanging out in a local Tavern, Meepo comes back and tells me how this mayor has intel on a cult that's using an old church as a place of worship. "Great! Let's go kill some Cultist." 

The plan was simple. The mayor even supplied us with the explosives to make it an easy job. So we snuck out at night, blew up the old church, and congratulated each other on a job well done. Afterwards, we made our way back into town. That's when the villagers greeted us. Or rather, that's where my story ends.

I didn't see the arrow in the night sky as it buried it's self into my heart. All I felt was the pain. Adrenalin must have kicked in because for the longest moment, everything seemed to stand still. I could see my friends near me. I could see the villagers, the anger on their face. I couldn't understand why they were so angry.

They say your life flashes before your eyes when you are dieing. It seems all the good times, and all the bad, flooded my vision. In that moment I realized something. The best moments of my life were spent with these two knuckleheads. So to you, Meepo and Kade, I say this.

Thank you for all the mountains we moved together. I had the time of my life slaying Dragons with you.
